page.title: 02PAKEFIELD PARISH CHURCH
page.content: Thousands of years ago a large sarcen stone was brought hundreds of miles by glaciers, deposited on this site and, later, became a centre of worship. The church of All Saints and St. Margaret, built over this stone is, to-day, a prominent {landmark}, being situated on the very edge of the cliff. The {church} is unusual in that it was once two medieties with two parallel naves separated by a wall. Parts of the present church date from the 14th century. The two churches were combined into one in the 15th century. During World War II a German incendiary bomb ignited the thatch and almost completely destroyed the church. It was rebuilt in 1951 in the original style using the same local flint. The square tower houses 8 bells which are rung regularly for services.
